docs.lead_paragraph: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1984 The Economy New home construction rose a strong 15 percent in January from December, to an annual rate of 1.92 million units, the highest level in five years. Although the rise came after weak results the month before, Government and private economists said the good performance should continue. Higher demand and stable mortgage rates were cited as causes. (Page D1.)

docs.lead_paragraph: Three leading health organizations today accused the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and other tobacco companies of ''misleading'' and ''irresponsible'' advertising that presented a false picture of the health consequences of smoking. At a news conference punctuated by unusually harsh language, officials of the American Heart Association, American Cancer Society and American Lung Association charged that a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign by Reynolds to cast doubt on the scientific evidence against smoking was nothing more than ''a smokescreen'' by a ''desperate industry.'' The organizations said the campaign, which began recently, sought to hide from the public that ''an overwhelming amount of scientific evidence'' showed ''cigarettes are this country's major health hazard.'' They also charged that tobacco companies had increasingly violated the industry's advertising code by promoting cigarettes to youth audiences and by portraying ballet dancers, skiers, mountain climbers and other athletic individuals relaxing with cigarettes.
